crossingNotPermitted.element2a: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian on the pavement where cycling was prohibited. You would need to show that the other party is at fault so that a case could be brought against them, which may be challenging given that it is their right of way. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

crossingOffRoad.element2a: You were injured when a pedestrian crossed your path whilst you were cycling. You would need to show that the other party is at fault which may be challenging as you are expected to take care to avoid pedestrians who may be using the path. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

dooredPassenger.element2a: You were injured when a passenger opened a vehicle door into your path. On that basis it would normally appear that you had a good case, unless the door had been open for long enough for you to have safely stopped or manoeuvred around it.

dooredDriver.element2a: You were injured when the driver opened the driver door into your path. On that basis it would normally appear that you had a good case, unless the door had been open for long enough for you to have safely stopped or manoeuvred around it.

fromBehindObj.element2a: You were injured when a pedestrian stepped into your path whilst you were cycling. You have indicated that they stepped out from behind an object. This is positive for the case as it implies that you did not have any warning of the presence of the pedestrian and there was little you could have done to avoid the incident.

green.element2a: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian at a set of traffic lights which were green. Given that the light was green it was your right of way and the case would normally be strong. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail using the form at the bottom of the screen.

roundaboutL.element2a: You were injured when you were hit on a roundabout by a vehicle coming from your left. It sounds like you should have a good case given that it was your right of way.

offPavement.element2a: You were injured when a pedestrian stepped into your path whilst you were cycling. You have indicated that they stepped out from the pavement into your path. This is positive for the case as it implies that you did not have any warning of the presence of the pedestrian and there was little you could have done to avoid the incident. If the pedestrian can show that you ought to have been aware that they were crossing the road and had the opportunity to stop or slow down then this may weaken your case.

oncomingAcrossPathAdvice.filteringNo: You were injured when the defendant turned right, into a side road, going across your path. It sounds like you should have a good case.
oncomingAcrossPathAdvice.filteringYes: You were injured when the defendant turned right, into a side road, going across your path. You were filtering to the left of a queue of traffic when approaching a side road on your left. This is seen as a hazardous manoeuvre and - although your case is likely to win - you will normally have your damages reduced by around 50% for 'contributory negligence'. For more information see this guide – link.

oncomingOvertakingAdvice.element2a: You were injured when the defendant struck you when they strayed into your lane whilst overtaking right. It sounds like you should have a good case.

pedRanInto.element2a: You were injured when a pedestrian ran into the side of you whilst you were cycling. On that basis it would normally appear that you had a good case, unless the incident occurred where cycling was not permitted or where it was the defendant's right of way, such as on a pedestrian crossing.

rearEndedBy.element2a: You were injured when the defendant went into the back of you whilst you were cycling. It sounds like you should have a good case.

redAmber.element2a: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian at a set of traffic lights which were red/amber. Given that it was your right of way the case would normally be strong.

roadDefect.element2a: You were in an accident caused by a defect in the road. It is important to take photographs of the defect as soon as possible to show how it looked at the time of the accident. Go back to the scene to record the size of the defect and to take photographs with the tape measure in shot so you can accurately show how deep and wide it is. Cases for defects in the road are challenging. Even if you can show that the defect was a dangerous hazard, the highway authority need only show that they had a 'reasonable system of inspection' in place to avoid blame. The frequency of inspections required will often be once every 3 - 6 months, depending on the type of road. If the highway authority can show that they inspected the road within that timescale then you would need to show that they missed the defect or that they should have been aware of the defect in any event, such as if people had complained about the defect since the inspection.

vTurned2SideRoadAdvice.element2a: You were injured when you were in an incident with another road user as they were entering your road from a side road. The responsibility was on them to check that it was safe to proceed so your case sounds strong on that basis.

vTurned2ParkingAdvice.element2a: You were injured when you were in an incident with another road user as they were leaving a parking spot. The responsibility is on the other person to check that it was safe to proceed so your case sounds strong on that basis.

vTurned1ChangingLanesAdvice.element2a: You were injured when the defendant turned into you when they changed lanes. It sounds like you should have a good case.

vDirDetsSameQTurnIntoYouLAdvice.element2a: You were injured when the defendant turned into you when they were turning into a side road. It sounds like you should have a good case.

vDirDetsSameQTurnIntoYouRAdvice.filteringNo: You were injured when the defendant, whose vehicle was travelling in the same direction as you, turned into you while turning right. It sounds like you should have a good case.
vDirDetsSameQTurnIntoYouRAdvice.filteringYes: You were injured when the defendant, whose vehicle was travelling in the same direction as you, turned into you while turning right. You were filtering to the right of a queue of traffic when approaching a side road on your right. This is seen as a hazardous manoeuvre and - although your case is likely to win - you will normally have your damages reduced by around 50% for 'contributory negligence'. For more information see this guide – link.

changingLanes.title: I think I will need more infomation
changingLanes.reason: You were injured when you were hit on a roundabout by a vehicle whilst you changed lanes. It is difficult to say who is to blame without further information. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

contactMe.title: I think I will need more infomation
contactMe.reason: I have not been able to work out the circumstances of the incident. If you want me to consider it please send me an email with some more detail.

amber.title: I think I will need more infomation
amber.reason: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian at a set of traffic lights which were amber. You would need to show that the other party is at fault, which may be challenging in the circumstances as amber is only an indication to proceed and you still need to look out for pedestrians. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

iDets2RanRedLightAdvice.title: I think I will need more infomation
iDets2RanRedLightAdvice.reason: You were injured when you were in an incident with another road user when you jumped a red light. You would need to show that the other party is at fault which may be challenging as they can argue that they did not anticipate your actions and it was their right of way. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

iDets2PaveAdvice.title: I think I will need more infomation
iDets2PaveAdvice.reason: You were injured when you were in an incident with another road user whilst you were cycling on the pavement where cycling was prohibited. You would need to show that the other party is at fault which may be challenging as they can argue that they did not expect to see you there. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

manoeuvringAdvice.title: I think I will need more infomation
manoeuvringAdvice.reason: You were injured when you were in an incident with another road user when you were manoeuvring around / overtaking another vehicle on your bicycle. You would need to show that the other party is at fault which will depend on the exact circumstances of the incident. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

roundaboutR.title: I think I will need more infomation
roundaboutR.reason: You were injured when you were hit on a roundabout by a vehicle coming from your right. It sounds like a challenging case as they would have had the right of way. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

notPermitted.title: I think I will need more infomation
notPermitted.reason: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian on a path where cycling was prohibited. You would need to show that the other party is at fault so that a case could be brought against them, which may be challenging given that it is their right of way. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail using the form at the bottom of the screen.

pedCrossing.title: I think I will need more infomation
pedCrossing.reason: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian on a pedestrian crossing. You would need to show that the other party is at fault so that a case could be brought against them, which will be challenging given that it is their right of way. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

pedStationary.title: I think I will need more infomation
pedStationary.reason: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian who was stationary. You would need to show that the other party is at fault so that a case could be brought against them, which may be challenging in the circumstances. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

permittedPath.title: I think I will need more infomation
permittedPath.reason: You were injured when a pedestrian crossed your path whilst you were cycling. You would need to show that the other party is at fault which may be challenging as you are expected to take care to avoid pedestrians who may be using the path. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

youRearEnded.title: I think I will need more infomation
youRearEnded.reason: You were injured when you were in an incident with another road user when you rode into the back of them on your bicycle. You would need to show that the other party is at fault which may be challenging in the circumstances. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

red.title: I think I will need more infomation
red.reason: You were injured when you cycled into a pedestrian at a set of traffic lights which were red. You would need to show that the other party is at fault, which may be challenging in the circumstances given that it was their right of way. If you would like further advice please send me a message with more detail.

bikesOnly.title: I'm afraid that this tool is only for cyclists who have been injured.
bikesOnly.reason: Feel free to send me a message if you would like me to point you in the direction of a solicitor who may be able to help and I will respond with some suggestions. I will not pass your details on to anyone else.

hitAndRun.reason: If a driver/motorcyclist does not stop at the scene of an incident, you may still be able to get compensation through the Motor Insurance Bureau (MIB). All motor insurance policies contribute to this fund which covers hit and run incidents and also incidents caused by uninsured drivers. There are strict time limits for these claims, including having to report the incident to the Police within 5 days if you want to claim for damage to personal property. The time limits can be found here, along with details on how to apply for compensation: http://www.mib.org.uk/Submit+a+Claim/en/Default.htm Make a MIB claim. Alternatively, feel free to send me a message if you have any other queries. I will not pass your details on to anyone else. If you were hit by an uninsured vehicle and it was their fault then you can bring a claim through the Motor Insurance Bureau (MIB). All motor vehicle insurance policies pay into this fund which compensates those injured in hit and run incidents or by uninsured drivers. If you want to make a claim via the MIB you can complete the relevant form here: Hit and run: click here Uninsured driver: click here Please note that you have 2 years from the date of the incident in which to lodge the form with the MIB otherwise you will not be able to make a claim. If you have any property damage then a claim form must be lodged with the MIB within 6 months of the date of the incident.

jurisdiction.title: I'm afraid that this tool is only for incidents occurring in England or Wales as the law in other jurisdictions is different and you will need specialist advice.
jurisdiction.reason: Feel free to send me a message if you would like me to point you in the direction of a solicitor who may be able to help and I will respond with some suggestions. I will not pass your details on to anyone else.

timeBarred.title: I'm afraid that you are proabably too late to bring a case.
timeBarred.reason: As your incident occurred either over 3 years ago or 3 years since you 18th birthday your case is out of time and will be statute barred. If you were unable to bring a case during this time due to lack of capacity then this may mean you are able to still bring a case. Also, the courts have the discretion to allow a case to proceed out of time in special circumstances. If you think you may have a good reason for not bringing a case within limitation period please feel free to send me a message. I will not pass your details on to anyone else.

roadDefectLetter.materialTimes: the authority responsible for the highway in question.
roadDefectLetter.afterLandmark: I hit a pothole, leading me to fall from my bicycle.
roadDefectLetter.liability1: For failing to institute any or any reasonable system of inspection for the relevant highway.
roadDefectLetter.liability2: For failing to repair a dangerous defect on the highway.
roadDefectLetter.liabilityResult: The result of the above was in breach of section 41 of the Highways Act 1980. It is clear in my view that liability attaches to

injuredByAnimalLetter.materialTimes: a pet owner responsible for the pet in question.
injuredByAnimalLetter.afterLandmark: the pet ran across my path causing me to fall from my bicycle.
injuredByAnimalLetter.liability1: For failing to control your pet.
injuredByAnimalLetter.liability2: For failing to take any reasonable precautions to ensure that your pet did not cause injury of the type claimed.
injuredByAnimalLetter.liability3: For failing to consider the harm that would be caused by failing to control your pet.
injuredByAnimalLetter.liabilityResult: As a result of the above it is clear in my view that liability attaches to

injuredByPedestrianLetter.afterLandmark: stepped into my path causing me to fall from my bicycle.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability1: For suddenly and without warning walking into my path.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability2: For causing me to fall from my bicycle.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability3: For failing to heed my presence.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability5: For failing to keep a proper lookout.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability6: For failing to cross the road in a safe manner.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability7: For failing to avoid colliding with me.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability8: For failing to apply Rule 7 of the Highway Code.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability9: For failing to apply Rule 14 of the Highway Code.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability10: For failing to apply Rule 17 of the Highway Code.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liability11: For failing to apply Rule 12 of the Highway Code.
injuredByPedestrianLetter.liabilityResult: As a result of the above it is clear in my view that liability attaches to

rearEndedByLetter.materialTimes: in charge the vehicle in question.
rearEndedByLetter.afterLandmark: I was rear-ended by the vehicle in question which had been travelling behind me.
rearEndedByLetter.liability2: For failing to brake in time if at all.
rearEndedByLetter.liability3: For failing to swerve out of the way.
rearEndedByLetter.liability4: For failing to drive at a speed suitable in all the circumstances.
rearEndedByLetter.liability5: For failing to keep a proper lookout.
